Many previous studies adopted the instantaneous reproduction number, commonly denoted by R
t , which can be estimated by a renewable equation, to quantify the transmissibility of infectious diseases [ 21, 23, 24, 37, 38]. The factors that affect the changing dynamics of R
t include
the depletion of the susceptible population [ 32] or decrease in the exposure to infectious sources,
the change, usually it is the improvement, in the unmeasurable disease control efforts, e.g. contract tracing, travel restriction, school closure, etc., [ 39â€“ 42] and local awareness of the epidemic [ 33], and
the natural features of the pathogen, e.g. its original infectivity and other interepidemic factors [ 32, 33, 35].
